fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Set is cocomplete.

By the cocompleteness criterion, it suffices to give coproducts and coequalizers. Coproducts are given by the disjoint union. The coequalizer of functions A\overset {f,g}{\rightrightarrows } B is B / \sim , where \sim is the equivalence relation generated by f(a) \sim g(a) for all a \in A, and / denotes the quotient of sets.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Category theory in context

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Suitable for advanced undergraduates and graduate students in mathematics, the text provides tools for understanding and attacking difficult problems in algebra, number theory, algebraic geometry, and algebraic topology. Drawing upon a broad range of mathematical examples from the categorical perspective, the author illustrates how the concepts and constructions of category theory arise from and illuminate more basic mathematical ideas. Prerequisites are limited to familiarity with some basic set theory and logic.
A (pre)set is a collection of some pre-mathematical elements. We write x\in X to denote that x is an element of the set X.
A (set-)function consists of two sets, the domain and the codomain, and a rule (say, a derivation) that assigns to each element of the domain a unique element of the codomain.
The category of sets Set is the category whose objects are sets and whose morphisms are set-functions.

fr:title.text: Elementary theory of the category of sets

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Elementary theory of the category of sets

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Lawvere's elementary theory of the category of sets asserts that the category of sets is the well-pointed topos with choice and a natural numbers object.
An injection is a monomorhpism in Set. Explicitly, a map A\xrightarrow {f} B is injective if, for every x,y\in A, f(x)=f(y) implies x=y.
An surjection is an epimorphism in Set. Explicitly, a map A\xrightarrow {f} B is surjective if, for every y\in B, there exists an x\in A such that f(x)=y.
A bijection is an isomorphism in Set. Explicitly, a map is bijective if it is both injective and surjective.
A subset is a subobject in Set. Notationally, it is specified as \{x\in X: \phi (x)\}, where \phi (x) is the classifying map of the subobject.
The empty set \varnothing is the initial object in Set. Explicitly, it is the set with no elements.
The singleton set * is the terminal object in Set. Explicitly, it is the set with one element.
The cartesian product is the product in Set. Explicitly, the product of sets A and B is A\times B = \{(a, b) \mid a\in A, b\in B\}.
The disjoint union is the coproduct in Set. Explicitly, the disjoint union of sets A and B is A \sqcup B = \{(a, 0) \mid a \in A\} \cup \{(b, 1) \mid b \in B\}, where \cup denotes the union.
The function set is the exponential in Set. Explicitly, the function set of sets A and B is the set of functions B^A := \{f: A\to B\}.
An equivalence relation is a congruence in Set. Explicitly, it is a reflexive, symmetric, and transitive relation.
The quotient of a set X by an equivalence relation \sim is the set of equivalence classes of \sim , i.e. \{\{x: x\sim x_0\}: x_0\in X\}.
Set is complete.

By the completeness criterion, it suffices to give products and equalizers. Products are given by the cartesian product. The equalizer of functions A\overset {f,g}{\rightrightarrows }B is \{a\in A: f(a) = b(a)\}.

Let J\xrightarrow {D} Set be a small diagram. We define \operatorname *{lim} D = \operatorname *{Cone}_D(*) = \operatorname {Hom}(*, D), where * is the constant functor at the singleton and \operatorname *{Cone} is the cone functor. Note that this is indeed a set, because J is small. An element of this set is a natural transformation *\xrightarrow {\mu } D, which consists of a morphism *\xrightarrow {\mu _j} Dj for each j\in J, hence canonically identifies a J-tuple of elements (x_i\in Dj). The legs of should be maps \operatorname *{lim} D\xrightarrow {\lambda } Dj; we define these by (*\xrightarrow {\mu } D)\xmapsto {\lambda _j} \mu _j(*).

To show that this cone is limiting, let Z\xrightarrow {
u } D be a cone. We need to show that 
u factors uniquely through \lambda . An element z\in Z identifies a map *	o Z, and hence a cone *	o Z\xrightarrow {
u } D, which is thus an element t(z)\in \operatorname *{lim} D. Now \lambda _j(t(z)) = (
u z)_j = 
u _j(z), and so 
u = \lambda t, as desired. It remains to show uniqueness, but any function Z\xrightarrow {u} \operatorname *{lim} D factoring 
u must satisfy u(z)_j = \lambda _j(u(z)) = 
u _j(z) = (
u z)_j = t(z)_j, so we are done.
Set is cocomplete.

By the cocompleteness criterion, it suffices to give coproducts and coequalizers. Coproducts are given by the disjoint union. The coequalizer of functions A\overset {f,g}{\rightrightarrows } B is B / \sim , where \sim is the equivalence relation generated by f(a) \sim g(a) for all a \in A, and / denotes the quotient of sets.
The union A \cup B of two subsets A,B\subseteq X is the subset \{x\in X: x\in A\text { or }x\in B\}.
The intersection A \cup B of two subsets A,B\subseteq X is the subset \{x\in X: x\in A\text { and }x\in B\}.
The complement A^c of a subset A\subseteq X is the subset \{x\in X: x\notin A\}.

fr:title.text: Complete Boolean algebra structure on power sets

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Complete Boolean algebra structure on power sets

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The power set 2^X of a set X forms a complete Boolean algebra under union, intersection, and complement.
The natural numbers \mathbb {N} = \{0, 1, \dots \} are the natural numbers object in Set.

The integers \mathbb {Z} = \{\dots , -1, 0, 1, \dots \} are the quotient of the square \mathbb {N}\times \mathbb {N} of the natural numbers by the relation (n, m)\sim (n', m') \text { iff } n + m' = n' + m.

The rational numbers \mathbb {Q} are the quotient of the product \mathbb {Z}\times \mathbb {Z}\setminus 0 of the integers with the integers without zero by the relation (p, q)\sim (p', q')\text { iff } pq' = qp'.
The real numbers \mathbb {R} are TODO.
A commutatitive diagram in a category C is a functor J\xrightarrow {D} C. The domain J is called the indexing category or the shape of the diagram.

A cone over a diagram J\xrightarrow {D} C with apex c\in C is a natural transformation c\xrightarrow {\lambda } D, where c is the constant functor at c. Explicitly, a cone consists of, for each object j\in J, a morphism c\xrightarrow {\lambda _j} Dj, so that for each morphism j\xrightarrow {f}k\in J, the following diagram commutes:
The components \lambda _j of the cone are called its legs.
A limit of a diagram is a universal cone.

By the definition of universal elements, a limit of a diagram J\xrightarrow {D} C consists of an object \operatorname *{lim} D\in C and a cone \operatorname *{lim} D\xrightarrow {\lambda } D which is universal in the sense that it induces, by the Yoneda lemma, a natural isomorphism C(-, \operatorname *{lim} D)\cong \operatorname *{Cone}_D.
Dually:
A colimit of a diagram is a universal cocone.

By the definition of universal elements, a colimit of a diagram J\xrightarrow {D} C consists of an object \operatorname *{colim} D\in C and a cocone D \xrightarrow {\lambda } \operatorname *{colim} D which is universal in the sense that it induces, by the Yoneda lemma, a natural isomorphism C(\operatorname *{colim} D, -)\cong \operatorname *{Cocone}_D.

fr:title.text: Map out of colimits, map into limits

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Map out of colimits, map into limits

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The universal property of limits makes it easy to construct morphisms into them; the universal property of colimits makes it easy to construct maps out of them.
A product is a limit of a discrete diagram. Its legs are called projections.
A coproduct is a colimit of a discrete diagram. Its colegs are called coprojections.
A pullback is a limit of a diagram of shape \bullet \to \bullet \leftarrow \bullet .
The symbol \lrcorner in the previous diagram denotes that the square is a pullback.
A pushout is a colimit of a diagram of shape \bullet \leftarrow \bullet \to \bullet .
The symbol \ulcorner in the previous diagram denotes that the square is a pushout.
An terminal object is a limit of an empty diagram.
By the universal property of limits, an object t is terminal in the category C if and only if for every object c, there is a unique morphism c\to t.
An initial object is a colimit of an empty diagram.
By the universal property of colimits, an object i is initial in the category C if and only if for every object c, there is a unique morphism i\to c.
An equalizer is a limit of a diagram of shape \bullet \rightrightarrows \bullet .
A coequalizer is a colimit of a diagram of shape \bullet \rightrightarrows \bullet .

fr:title.text: Limits are unique up to unique isomorphism

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Limits are unique up to unique isomorphism

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Limits are unique up to unique isomorphism of cones. Explicitly, let J\xrightarrow {d} C be a diagram and suppose x\xrightarrow {\lambda } D and y\xrightarrow {\mu } D are both limiting cones. Then there is a unique isomorphism x\to y commuting with the \lambda and \mu .
Dually, colimits are unique up to unique isomorphism of cocones.

This follows from the characterization of representable isomorphism, but we give a direct proof. To show isomorphism, note that the universal property of limits induces a pair of unique maps x\xtofrom [g]{f} y commuting with the cones; it remains to show these are isomorphisms. The composite gf is a map x\to x commuting with the cone \lambda , but 1_x is another such map, so by uniqueness of suchs maps gf = 1_x. The same works on the other side.
Let J\xrightarrow {F,G} C be naturally isomorphic diagrams. Then if their limits exist, they are isomorphic.
Taking limits is functorial and functors preserve isomorphism.
Let J be an index category and let C be J-complete. Then there is a functor C^J \xrightarrow {\operatorname *{lim}_J} C which acts on functors by taking the limit.
Note that this theorem relies on a choice of witnesses to the completeness of C, i.e. a canonical choice of limit of each J-shaped diagram.

Let I\times J\xrightarrow {F} C be a bifunctorial diagram such that the limits \operatorname *{lim}_I \operatorname *{lim}_J F and \operatorname *{lim}_J \operatorname *{lim}_I F exist. Then \operatorname *{lim}_{I\times J} F exists, and the three limits are isomorphic.

Since representable isomorphism implies isomorphism, it suffices to prove that C(X, \operatorname *{lim}_I \operatorname *{lim}_J F) \cong C(X, \operatorname *{lim}_{I\times J} F) \cong C(X, \operatorname *{lim}_J \operatorname *{lim}_I F) naturally in X. Since hom functors preserve limits, the desired result becomes \operatorname *{lim}_I \operatorname *{lim}_J C(X, F) \cong \operatorname *{lim}_{I\times J} C(X, F) \cong \operatorname *{lim}_J \operatorname *{lim}_I C(X, F); i.e., the general case reduces to that of Set. By the isomorphism I\times J\cong J\times I, it suffices to prove the first isomorphism.

The proof is essentially by currying. Let I\times J\xrightarrow {G} Set be a diagram. By the construction of limits in Set, the limit \operatorname *{lim}_J G(i, -) is the set of cones over G(i, -) with summit *, hence equivalently the set of J-tuples (x_j\in G(i, j)) satisfying G(i, f)(x_j) = x_{j'} for each j\xrightarrow {f}j'\in J. Taking the limit over I, we now conclude that \operatorname *{lim}_I \operatorname *{lim}_J G consists of the tuples (x_{ij}\in G(i, j)) which commute with G-images of maps in I and J. This is exactly the data of \operatorname *{lim}_{I\times J} G.

Let I\times J\xrightarrow {F} C be a bifunctorial diagram such that the following limits and colimits exist. Then there is a canonical map \operatorname *{colim}_I \operatorname *{lim}_J F\to \operatorname *{lim}_J \operatorname *{colim}_I F.
In particular, the map goes from a colimit to a limit because colimits are easy to map out of, while limits are easy to map into.

fr:title.text: Limits and colimits in functor categories are computed pointwise

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Limits and colimits in functor categories are computed pointwise

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let A be a small category. Then where \operatorname *{obj} C is the discrete category of objects, the forgetful functor C^A\to C^{\operatorname *{obj} A} strictly creates all limits and colimits in C. For each a\in A, the evaluation at a functor C^A\to C preserves all limits and colimits which exist in C.

We prove the result for limits and conclude for colimits by duality. For any diagram J\xrightarrow {D} C, the definition of \operatorname {Hom}(\Delta c, D) is the set of natural transformations c\to D, which by definition is the set of cones \operatorname *{Cone}_D(c). A right adjoint \operatorname *{lim}_J to this functor is thus characterized by the natural isomorphism \operatorname {Hom}(\Delta c, D)\cong \operatorname *{Cone}_D(c)\cong C(c, \operatorname *{lim}_J D), which is the definition of the limit. Thus pointwise the right adjoint and the limit agree, and so the right adjoint extends uniquely to the limit functor.

Let J\xrightarrow {F} C be a diagram in a locally small category C whose limit exists. Then there is a natural isomorphism C(x, \operatorname *{lim} F)\cong \operatorname *{lim} C(x, F-), where the latter is a limit in Set.
Dually, let the colimit of F exist. Then there is a natural isomorphism C(\operatorname *{colim} F, x)\cong \operatorname *{lim}_{J^\text {op}} C(F-, x).

Let C be locally small. The hom bifunctor preserves limits in both arguments. In particular, covariant hom-functors preserve limits and contravariant hom-functors preserve colimits, and so representable functors preserve limits.

We show the result for covariant hom-functors. Let J\xrightarrow {F} C be a diagram in C with limit \operatorname *{lim} F\xrightarrow {\lambda _j} Fj. The image of this diagram under C(x, -) is the diagram J\xrightarrow {F} C\xrightarrow {C(x, -)} Set, which is a limit in Set by the representability of limits.

fr:title.text: Yoneda embedding preserves and reflects limits

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Yoneda embedding preserves and reflects limits

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The Yoneda embedding preserves and reflects limits.
Preservation of limits follows because hom-functors preserve limits and limits in functor categories are computed pointwise.
Reflection of limits follows because the Yoneda embedding is fully faithful and fully faithful functors reflect limits.
A category is complete if it has all small limits.
A category is cocomplete if it has all small colimits.
A category is complete if and only if it has all small products and equalizers.
Dually, a category is cocomplete if and only if it has all small coproducts and coequalizers.
The forwards direction is immediate, because products and equalizers are limits.
In the backwards direction, let J\xrightarrow {F} C be a small diagram. Now we define maps c and d using the universal property of the product as follows:

To demonstrate the universal property of the limit, let z\xrightarrow {\mu } F be another cone over F. Then the legs of the cone yield a map z\to \prod _{j\in J} Fj by the universal property of the product. Since it is a cone, hence commutes with Ff, this map equalizes the previous diagram. We obtain the desired result by the universal property of the equalizer.
Set is complete.

By the completeness criterion, it suffices to give products and equalizers. Products are given by the cartesian product. The equalizer of functions A\overset {f,g}{\rightrightarrows }B is \{a\in A: f(a) = b(a)\}.

Let J\xrightarrow {D} Set be a small diagram. We define \operatorname *{lim} D = \operatorname *{Cone}_D(*) = \operatorname {Hom}(*, D), where * is the constant functor at the singleton and \operatorname *{Cone} is the cone functor. Note that this is indeed a set, because J is small. An element of this set is a natural transformation *\xrightarrow {\mu } D, which consists of a morphism *\xrightarrow {\mu _j} Dj for each j\in J, hence canonically identifies a J-tuple of elements (x_i\in Dj). The legs of should be maps \operatorname *{lim} D\xrightarrow {\lambda } Dj; we define these by (*\xrightarrow {\mu } D)\xmapsto {\lambda _j} \mu _j(*).

To show that this cone is limiting, let Z\xrightarrow {
u } D be a cone. We need to show that 
u factors uniquely through \lambda . An element z\in Z identifies a map *	o Z, and hence a cone *	o Z\xrightarrow {
u } D, which is thus an element t(z)\in \operatorname *{lim} D. Now \lambda _j(t(z)) = (
u z)_j = 
u _j(z), and so 
u = \lambda t, as desired. It remains to show uniqueness, but any function Z\xrightarrow {u} \operatorname *{lim} D factoring 
u must satisfy u(z)_j = \lambda _j(u(z)) = 
u _j(z) = (
u z)_j = t(z)_j, so we are done.
Set is cocomplete.

By the cocompleteness criterion, it suffices to give coproducts and coequalizers. Coproducts are given by the disjoint union. The coequalizer of functions A\overset {f,g}{\rightrightarrows } B is B / \sim , where \sim is the equivalence relation generated by f(a) \sim g(a) for all a \in A, and / denotes the quotient of sets.

Let I\xrightarrow {F} Top be a diagram in spaces. Then the limit of F has underlying set the limit in Set, topologized by the initial topology: the coarsest topology making the legs \pi _\alpha of the limiting cone continuous.
Explicitly, the initial topology is generated by the subbase \bigcup _{\alpha } \{\pi _\alpha ^{-1}(U): U\subseteq F\alpha \text { open}\}.
Furthermore, the colimit of F has underlying set the colimit in Set, topologized by the final topology: the finest topology making the colegs \iota _\alpha of the colimiting cocone continuous.
Explicitly, a subset U of the colimit is open in the final topology if and only if \iota _\alpha ^{-1}(U) is open for each \alpha .
We give the proof for limits; the proof for colimits is identical. That (X, \pi _\alpha ) is a cone over D is immediate because the initial topology makes the \pi _\alpha continuous.

Let (Z, \tau _\alpha ) be a cone in Top over D. Let f: Z\to X be the canonical map induced by the universal property of the limit in Set. It now remains to show that f is continuous, but this comes precisely from the construction of the initial topology.

fr:title.text: Presheaf categories are complete and cocomplete

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Presheaf categories are complete and cocomplete

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Every presheaf category is complete and cocomplete, with limits and colimits computed as in Set.
Limits and colimits are computed pointwise and Set is complete and cocomplete.
An equivalence relation is a congruence in Set. Explicitly, it is a reflexive, symmetric, and transitive relation.
The quotient of a set X by an equivalence relation \sim is the set of equivalence classes of \sim , i.e. \{\{x: x\sim x_0\}: x_0\in X\}.
A category is complete if and only if it has all small products and equalizers.
Dually, a category is cocomplete if and only if it has all small coproducts and coequalizers.
The forwards direction is immediate, because products and equalizers are limits.
In the backwards direction, let J\xrightarrow {F} C be a small diagram. Now we define maps c and d using the universal property of the product as follows:

To demonstrate the universal property of the limit, let z\xrightarrow {\mu } F be another cone over F. Then the legs of the cone yield a map z\to \prod _{j\in J} Fj by the universal property of the product. Since it is a cone, hence commutes with Ff, this map equalizes the previous diagram. We obtain the desired result by the universal property of the equalizer.
The disjoint union is the coproduct in Set. Explicitly, the disjoint union of sets A and B is A \sqcup B = \{(a, 0) \mid a \in A\} \cup \{(b, 1) \mid b \in B\}, where \cup denotes the union.
A category is cocomplete if it has all small colimits.
A coequalizer is a colimit of a diagram of shape \bullet \rightrightarrows \bullet .
A coproduct is a colimit of a discrete diagram. Its colegs are called coprojections.
A morphism in a category is an endomorphism if its domain and codomain agree.
This note is still to do.
